I think the people that assume the silkworms suffer aren’t looking at the whole picture.

For one, the silkworms and the moths live carefree lives in the farms. They’re provided ample food, live in an environment without harsh conditions, and are protected from predators and disease. While it is kinda sad the moths cannot fly, they’re otherwise completely fine, you must remember many moth species die very quickly once they turn into adults, as they emerge without mouthparts.

There’s also methods of harvesting silk that don’t kill the pupa. They’re not as common as the silk is damaged, but they’re prevalent and something worth noting.

Pupa that are killed in the process don’t go to waste, either. They’re edible and a delicacy in many countries. And IIRC they make for good compost, too.

This scares me, I have a mulberry tree (multiple actually) in my backyard and every spring and summer a bunch of these silkworms make a nest on a bunch of the branches. I always wondered about them. But why this is so scary is that moths are my #1 fear in the world. I can't explain why, they just are. And not long ago, my friend frightened me with a picture of a fully grown silk moth, and I had no connection in my brain that they were somehow related. But now that I know this... It worked to protect the Scythians from arrows, not like metal by stopping the arrow, but by yielding to it for a space but preventing it from penetrating very deeply. The Scythians were such fierce and frightening warriors they were the cause of China building the Great Wall.

comment_text: I was planning to set up my own silk farm
That’s so sad they can’t live in the wild anymore!

There is a type of silk mostly made in India called Ahimsa silk - Ahimsa translates to peace. The silk farmers don't kill the pupa inside the cotton, but allow the silk moth to develop fully and break out of the cocoon. It's a practice and technique that's been practiced for the past 20-30 years only. It is a nonviolent way of making silk, inspired by the nonviolent Buddhist philosophies.
Ahimsa silk is often more expensive than regular silk, however. And it is harder on the spinners to make silk thread, because the strands are shorter.Sgill, quite inspiring!

As a kid growing up in Japan, we called silk worms (kaiko in Japanese) as Kaiko-Sama. We use -sama as a way to address those whom we revere or regard highly of, such as divine entities and honorable people.

I think ancient people started calling the silk worms with an elevated address to show gratitude to the silk moths and worms. It’s a curious relationship, and I’m sure they were aware of it — to harvest unbroken silk, they had to boil them, which is a cruel practice; for the precious silk obtained in exchange for their lives, they showed reverence and gratitude to them.
See? Capitalism doesn't only exploit people, it can exploit defenseless creatures. 🥰

As a hobbyist entomologist who has raised many kinds of moths and butterflies, something that always bothers me when left out is the silkworms’ relatively common fate if they ARE allowed to emerge from their cocoons. Like many other moths, they eclose without mouth parts- the adults survive just around a week or so on all the lipids and proteins from the mulberry they ate before pupating. The silkworms don’t have a few months or so to enjoy life as adults- their purpose at that point is to breed as much as possible before dying of starvation. When people talk about how cruel sericulture is I think they usually don’t know this, because being boiled is certainly a much quicker, probably less painful and stressful way to die. They don’t even know what’s happening as they’re being brought to the pots. If you had a sick dog that you knew didn’t have long, would you give it a swift and sure euthanasia, or would you leave it to starve and succumb after days if not weeks?
Fabulous ❤️

Now I don't know what would become of the pupae once they've been boiled in an industrial silk manufaturing setting, but in small-scale silk manufacturers in Vietnam they would be stir-fried with spices and chopped lime leaves to be served as a delicacy. I believe elsewhere around Asia silkworm pupae would also be consumed as human food, which IMO is a great way to prevent these protein-rich resources from going to waste

I imagine that they lost their ability to fly and camouflage with respect to their needs to reproduce under virtually no outside threat (when allowed to hatch) and the abundance of food they are born and grown having.

This can be seen in two ways of course: they live so happily and abundantly in their larval state that their evolution abandoned any defensive capabilities in light of such a risk-free environment. Or, their DNA now knows that, for whatever reason, they will never make it past their pupal stage, and thus saw to it that any energy spent in their adult form was in vain.
